title: Is 60% of student debt held by 'rich and upper-middle class'?
summary: U.S. Rep. Glenn Grothman claimed that nearly 60% of all U.S. student loan debt is held by the rich and upper-middle class, suggesting loan forgiveness would primarily benefit the wealthy. An analysis from EducationData.org indicated that Americans with incomes over $74,000, who are considered middle to upper-middle class, hold about 60% of public student loan debt. However, it challenges Grothman's characterization of this group as 'rich.' While student loan forgiveness could significantly help low-income individuals who do carry debt, research and expert opinion suggest that wealthier people, who generally incur more debt due to attending graduate school, would gain more in absolute terms. Both the Brookings Institute and economic experts highlight that poorer individuals are less likely to have substantial student debt or attend college but would benefit proportionately more when they do have debt. Consequently, Grothman's assertion is rated as 'Half True' since it contains elements of truth but oversimplifies the impact on low-income individuals.

title: 5 Reasons Why Student Loan Forgiveness Is A Bad Idea - Forbes
summary: In a detailed speech, Sen. Roy Blunt outlined five reasons why he believes student loan forgiveness is a bad policy. First, he argues it disproportionately benefits wealthier Americans, with more than 80% not having student loans and over 60% of the debt held by households earning over $74,000. Second, he claims President Biden lacks the legal authority for broad forgiveness without Congress. Third, Blunt notes Biden hasn't prioritized wide-scale forgiveness, having targeted specific groups instead. Fourth, he warns it could increase inflation rather than lower it. Fifth, he suggests it might raise college costs by encouraging future borrowers to expect not to repay, sending the wrong message about personal responsibility. Blunt contrasts this with the potential benefits proposed by forgiveness supporters, who see it as an economic stimulant and a way to reduce disparities.
snippet: Notably, 60% of student loan debt is held by households that earn more than $74,000 of income annually. According to Blunt, student loan forgiveness disproportionately benefits wealthier Americans .

title: Student LoansWho Really Owes $1.6 Trillion Of Debt? - Forbes
summary: 45 million borrowers owe over $1.6 trillion in student loan debt, with over 90% stemming from federal loans. High-income households owe 60% of this debt and make 75% of payments. Conversely, lower-income households owe less than 20% and may benefit from income-driven repayment plans. Only 6% of borrowers owe more than $100,000, while 2% exceed $200,000. Around 18% owe less than $5,000, representing 1% of the total debt. Most debt (56%) comes from graduate studies, with higher income generally correlating with advanced degrees. Brookings highlights that broad student loan forgiveness might not effectively aid those most impacted by financial struggles exacerbated by Covid-19, and could increase economic inequality. Recommendations include student loan refinancing, consolidation, income-driven repayment plans, and forgiveness through public service.

title: Study: Most Student Debt Belongs To High-Wealth Households - Forbes
summary: A report from economist Adam Looney, featured in Forbes, reveals that most student debt is held by high-wealth households. Looney criticizes the common practice of assessing debt without considering the educational investments it finances. Before adjusting for the value of education, 53% of student debt appears to be held by the lowest wealth quintile, but this drops to 8% when educational value is included. The report suggests high-wealth households often have large debts due to costly but lucrative degrees. Mass student debt forgiveness is seen as regressive, benefiting those who may already have a high lifetime income due to their education. While the average bachelor's degree offers financial benefits, 28% do not yield a positive return, often due to dropouts or low-paying majors. The report calls for targeted reforms to assist distressed borrowers, such as eliminating delinquency fees and regulating educational investments to prevent excessive risk.
